story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Recommendation made by expert Joint Biosecurity Centre and approved by chief medical officersThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.The official UK coronavirus alert level has been cut from 4 to 3, signalling that transmission of the disease is no longer regarded as high.Health secretary Matt Hancock hailed the move as a big moment for the country and praised the contribution of the public in getting the virus under control by complying with lockdown rules.The green-light for the change came from the expert Joint Biosecurity Centre, which recommended a reduction in the level. It was jointly approved by the chief medical officers of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Hancock said:  “The UK moving to a lower alert level is a big moment for the country, and a real testament to the British people’s determination to beat this virus.“The government’s plan is working. Infection rates are rapidly falling, we have protected the NHS and, thanks to the hard work of millions in our health and social care services, we are getting the country back on her feet.”The change is likely to pave the way for further relaxations of the lockdown restrictions introduced by Boris Johnson in March. It will raise hopes that ministers will soon confirm the reopening of pubs and restaurants and permission for overnight stays in hotels and B&ampBs from 4 July.Seven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreak‘They can blame it for everything’: What coronavirus means for BrexitThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxDo you need a face mask and where can you buy one?UK lockdown: Can I see my family and friends under new rules?But the chief medical officers warned that it did not mean the pandemic is over. They cautioned that localised outbreaks are likely to occur and urged the public to continue following safety guidelines.The UK has remained at Level 4 of the alert system since its introduction in May, signifying that a Covid-19 epidemic is in general circulation and transmission is high or rising exponentially.Level 3 indicates that the epidemic is in general circulation, but crucially makes clear that experts do not regard either the prevalence of the disease as high or its spread as rapid.In a joint statement, the CMOs for the four nations of the UK said they had reviewed the evidence and agreee with the JBC’s recommendation to move to Level 3 across the entire country.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The virus is still in general circulation, and localised outbreaks are likely to occur.“We have made progress against the virus thanks to the efforts of the public and we need the public to continue to follow the guidelines carefully to ensure this progress continues.”When first announced in the government’s coronavirus recovery plan in May, the alert level was presented as the key to easing lockdown restrictions.The plan stated that the timing of measures like the reopening of shops and the return of children to schools “must be warranted by the current alert level”.But in the event, the government went ahead with two waves of relaxation on 1 and 15 June without the JBC assessing that the risk level had fallen.At the time of the first set of adjustments to guidelines, Mr Hancock revealed that the Centre was not even up and running yet. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Rodents pick up infections as they are moved through the supply chain,&nbspsuggests researchRats destined for Southeast Asia’s markets and restaurants have been found to carry multiple coronaviruses, a new study shows, adding to concerns over the trade in wild animals.While the strains detected in the rodents are different from the Covid-19 disease that caused the ongoing pandemic, researchers say their findings highlight the dangers of transporting large numbers of animals together in confined spaces.A collaborative study by researchers from the US and Vietnam found that the proportion of positive coronavirus cases increased as traders moved the live animals from fields to markets and eateries.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe results suggest that the rats had been picking up infections in transit, with the mixing of multiple coronaviruses representing “maximal risk for end consumers”.“While these aren’t dangerous viruses they offer information on how viruses can be amplified under these conditions,” said Sarah Olson of the US-based Wildlife Conservation Society, which led the study.China removes pangolin scales from list of traditional medicinesRats are a common protein source in some parts of Asia, with some communities relying on them as cheap source of meat. In Vietnam, rats are caught in rice fields – some traders breed them in farms with other live animals.For years scientists have warned that the wildlife trade – including wet markets that sell live animals – can harbour infectious diseases such as coronaviruses.The origins of the current Covid-19 pandemic remain contested. However, experts suspect that the disease started in bats and was transferred to another animal before being passed on to humans.The study, published in the bioRxiv journal ahead of peer-review, found six known coronaviruses in samples taken from three southern provinces in Vietnam between 2013 and 2014.New York rats feel the pressure of city livingPositives increased significantly along the supply chain. Around 6 per cent of the rats tested on farms were found to harbour coronaviruses. This grew to 21 per cent among rodents handled by traders, 32 per cent at large markets and 56 per cent in restaurants.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. coronaviruses.”The study focused on rats only but the researchers believe the findings could apply to other traded wild animals such as pangolins.Vietnam is considering a ban on wildlife trade and consumption while China last week removed pangolin parts from its list of traditional remedies, state-backed media reported.Pangolins – the world’s most trafficked mammal – are highly sought after in both countries for their meat, which is considered a delicacy, while their scales are used in traditional medicine and folk remedies.The move came after China’s forestry authority upgraded the status of pangolins to “first-level protected wild animal,” the highest possible protection status alongside pandas and tigers.Officials said pangolins were removed from the list due to “wild resources title: coronavirus italy water survey traces december
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Scientists find early evidence of virus&nbspin two northern citiesThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Traces of coronavirus have shown up in Italy’s water from December last year – suggesting the virus was circulating more than a month before the country reported its first cases. Scientists discovered the presence of SARS-Cov-2 – the virus which causes Covid-19 – in wastewater collected from two northern cities towards the end of 2019. Italy reported its first known infection in late January. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesGiuseppina La Rosa, an expert in environmental wastewater at the Italian National Institute of Health (ISS) who co-led the research, said the findings “may help us understand the beginning of virus circulation” in the country. The ISS looked at sewage samples collected from wastewater treatment plants in northern Italy between October 2019 and February 2020.Seven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreak‘They can blame it for everything’: What coronavirus means for BrexitThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxDo you need a face mask and where can you buy one?UK lockdown: Can I see my family and friends under new rules?Traces of coronavirus were discovered on 18 December – before the virus was known to have reached Italy – in samples from Milan and Turin, an analysis released on Thursday said.Small studies conducted by scientific teams in the Netherlands, France, Australia and elsewhere have found signs that the virus causing Covid-19 can be detected in sewage.Many countries are beginning to use wastewater sampling to track the spread of the disease.Ms La Rosa said the detection of traces of the virus before the end of 2019 was consistent with evidence emerging in other countries about when coronavirus had entered their borders. Scientists in France have discovered a hospitalised man was infected with the virus as early as 29 December – nearly a month before France confirmed its first cases.Ms La Rosa said the presence of the virus in the Italian waste samples did not “automatically imply that the main transmission chains that led to the development of the epidemic in our country originated from these very first cases”.Samples positive for traces of the virus that causes Covid-19 were also found in sewage from Bologna, Milan and Turin in January and February, but all from October and November tested negative.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe institute said it plans to launch a pilot study in July to monitor wastewater at sites identified in tourist resorts.Northern Italy – where the researchers took their samples from – is where the worst outbreaks took place.  More than 92,500 people have tested positive for the virus in total in the badly-affected northern Lombardy region, which has a death toll of around 16,500. The whole country has seen a total of 238,159 infections as of Friday, according to official figures. Meanwhile, more than 34,500 people have died to date. story: But with Boris Johnson giving a massive hint that the two metre rule in schools could be cut, the lockdown looks like to be eased further in the UKs four nations.Lockdown restrictions are slowly being eased in dferent ways and at ying speeds across the UK, but July looks promisingHere we take a look at the situation in each of the four nations”The final step in the governments three-step plan is the most drastic easing of measures, allowing businesses like cinemas and restaurants to reopen - taking us into what is being dubbed the new normal.They are working towards an earliest possible opening date of July , which essential signals the end of lockdown.On Friday, June , Boris Johnson has given a massive hint that the two metre rule in schools could be cut, telling Brits to watch this space.days before new rules allowed all shops to open and permitted households to join another in a support bubblean adult lives alone or with a child.They also now permit people to be present at births, and to visit people who are seriously unwell.People can meet outdoors in groups of up to six, as long as they stay two metres apart.Guidance for people who are shielding also says they can go outdoors for exercise.On Thursday  June , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced that the country would be moving into phase two of its easing of restrictions, which will see changes made over the course of the coming days and weeks.People shielding can go outside for exercise and meet people from one other household.For the rest of the general public, up to three shield will be paused at the end of July.Childcare services will be available to all parents at the start of July and pupils in key year groups will alsoto school on August .Schools can also operate title: what r rate uk coronavirus
story: Officials are using the value to decide when to ease lockdown measures and often refer to it in the Covid- press briefings.R, or R nought, refers to the average number of people that one infected person can expect to pass the coronavirus on to.Scientists use it to predict how far and how fast a disease will spread - and the number can inform policy decisions about how to contain an outbreak.For example,a virus has an R of three, it means that each sick person will pass the disease on to three more people -no containment measures are introduced.Its also worth pointing out that title: summer 2020 solstice date
story: Yet, the date changes from year to year according to the stars alignment.The solstice marks its beginning while it comes to an end on the autumn equinox which will be on September .That date marks when day and night are of equal .This year the summer solstice falls on Saturday, June .It marks the day with the most about of daylight hours in the northern hemisphere, often referred to as the longest day of the year.The UK will enjoy  hours and  minutes of daylight.The sun will rise at .am and set at .pm.The summer solstice in the northern hemisphere always takes place sometime between June  and June .The midsummer date is set on the planet’s rotational axis.The summer solstice occurs when the tilt of Earths axis is most inclined towards the sun and is directly above the Tropic of Cancer.On the other hand, the summer solstice is the shortest day of the year in the Southern hemisphere.The term solstice derives from the Latin word solstitium, meaning sun standing still.The summer solstice in the south occurs between December  and December .The day is celebrated by pagans and druids, with rituals of rebirth performed throughout history on the day.One of the biggest celebrations in the UK occurs at Stonehenge with crowds gathering to watch the sunrise.The tradition sees revellers waiting by the Wiltshire monument on midsummer, facing towards the north-easterly direction.Crowds of devotees, often dressed for the occasion, regularly gather to watch the moment the sun rises above the Heel Stone.It’s just one of the many pagan festivals, which include midwinter and imbolc – the day that traditionally marks the start of spring.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris marcus rashford free school meals plea
story: The PM today declared that free school meals WILL be extended over the summer holidays, after a heroic campaign by England striker Marcus Rashford.Its a move that will benefit millions of disadvantaged families. And it couldnt come at a greater time of need: with our nation on the brink of the worst ever holiday hunger.The Covid pandemic has had a devastating financial impact on families up and down the country, with millions now struggling to keep a roof over their heads.Parents are, understandably, racked with anxiety over job losses, loved ones health and school closures, which have seen classrooms lie empty for  weeks.And this week, with the summer holidays looming, they faced another worry: how would they feed their children without free school meal vouchers Its a fear Rashford has bravely alleviated.The Man Utd star made an impassioned plea to the Government to prioritise Englands most vulnerable kids by extending the vouchers scheme over the six-week holidays.Under the programme, the families of around . million children eligible for free school meals are given £ a week in vouchers to spend in supermarkets to keep their kids fed.This is not about politics this is about humanity, Rashford wrote in an open letter. Political affiliations aside, can we not all agree that no child should be going to bed hungry The footballer was speaking from real experience: growing up in a low-income household in Manchester, his own family relied on free school meals and breakfast clubs.Today, a similar hand-to-mouth existence is being lived by millions of children across the country. And, in recent months, its been compounded by the coronavirus outbreak.Despite the Governments excellent furlough scheme, , Brits have lost their jobs during lockdown, with unemployment now set to hit the three million mark.As Rashford rightly observes, many families are living on a knes edge, gripped with fear over how they will pay their bills, cover their rent or even put food on the table.This is proven by new data from The Food Foundation, showing that food insecurity in households with children has nearly DOUBLED since the pandemic began.The research also reveals more than , youngsters have been forced to skip meals during lockdown because their family couldn’t access sufficient food.As Chair of the Commons Education Committee, I was delighted when, earlier this year, the Government extended its free school meals scheme for the Easter and May half-term holidays.Yet, like many, I believed its decision to halt the programme for the summer break was wrong.In my view, this was for three key reasons:Firstly, the vouchers have been a leline for many poverty-stricken families during the Covid lockdown. With further worrying and uncertain weeks ahead, these families need consistency.Secondly, and closely linked, is that millions of parents are struggling financially at the moment - something that may be exacerbated in August, when furlough contributions change.Feeding their kids over the summer will push their already stretched budgets to breaking point. Yet these youngsters desperately need, and deserve, nutritional meals.Thirdly, around three million children are at risk of holiday hunger every year .Extending the scheme was simply the right thing to do.It was also relatively easy: yes, its coming out of a £ million Covid Summer Food Fund, but unlike other schemes, it isnt bureaucratic and its understood by parents across England.It also goes to those who need it the most.Studies have shown that food poverty doesnt just impact on childrens health: malnourished kids are less likely to perform as well in the classroom as their better-off peers.This can shape the course of their adult le.England is already facing an educational Ice Ageschools cant open in September - by which point, children will have been out of education for six months.Despite parents home-schooling efforts,  per cent of teachers in the countrys most deprived areas have suggested their students are learning for less than one hour a day.And some , youngsters don’t have access to a computer or tablet at all.Its why Ive called for Alan Turing catch-up summer camps to be set up in school buildings, village halls and marquees - anywhere that can be used to educate our kids.Its also why, despite being a Tory MP, I publicly announced I would vote with Labour today and call on the Government to extend free school meals over the summer.To use a football analogy, it felt strange going to play for the opposite side. But like Rashford, I knew that impoverished families across the UK deserved more.Fortunately, Boris has seen sense, too.Amid this crisis, we need a bold vision from the PM about our childrens education: what are we going to do to get them learning again  How will we get them back to schools We need an exciting, confident agenda, because the next generation depends on it. With todays move, Boris has shown these families that, yes, we do mean business.As for Rashford, he has done as much -not more - for disadvantaged families than any politician. Hes brought a vital issue onto the national stage in a dignied way.Unlike virtue-signalling celebrities who fly on a plane from Los Angeles then go on about saving the environment, he has practised what he preaches.And in doing so, hes shown himself to be a nation icon on and off the pitch.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government parallel universe opinion
story: If they fancy studying one in slightly warmer climes, perhaps they should decamp to Britain.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAfter landing at Heathrow and filling out a form agreeing to a fortnight’s self-isolation, they could then hop on a train with, er, hundreds of other people and head in to the capital city, where, on a sunny day, they will pass ious parks that resemble Glastonbury Festival — a vast sprawl of people enjoying cheek-by-jowl picnics, washed down with alcohol purchased from a nearby supermarket.If they’re staying near London’s Oxford Street, they might observe the scrums at NikeTown and Primark, where thousands of desperate shoppers jostle for position, or they might chance upon " rel"noreferrer noopener"the warring factions of BLM and far-right protestors beating seven bells out of each other.And then, at around pm, they could tune in to the daily Government briefing where, flanked by two scientists, the PM or one of his ministers delivers grave warnings about the coronavirus, the possibility of a “second wave”, and how it is imperative we all continue to observe strict social-distancing measures.This, they justy regularly, is why the majority of workplaces are still shut, hundreds of thousands of children remain unschooled and the hospitality industry is on its knees.Parallel universe indeed.It’s often said that politicians live in “the Westminster bubble”, but it’s time they stepped outside of it and took a long hard look at what’s going on outside the confines of No.No one is listening any more. Well, the majority anyway.Be it scientist “Professor Lockdown” flouting his own advice, or Boris’s svengali Dominic Cummings bending the rules he helped make, the rot set in a couple of weeks ago and has now caused an undeniable fissure between the state and its initially compliant citizens.Yet, while thousands are blatantly breaking social distancing rules at parks, protests and shopping areas, many of them are still being furloughed — at vast taxpayer expense — to “stay home” from work.Whereas common sense dictates that being in an office that’s been health and safety-ed to the nth degree is a far more protected environment than any of the above.And what about schools  The majority of learning for GCSEs and A levels takes place in years  and  respectively, yet government plans for the " rel"noreferrer noopener"reopening of secondary schools remain “unclear”, with some reports saying they might not evenin September.Meaning that — on top of GCSEs and A levels being cancelled this year — hundreds of thousands of pupils will be in no position to take them next year either.If teenagers can gather in large, cheek-by-jowl groups at their local park, then surely ing to school isn’t beyond the pale  It might even be safer.As for the hospitality industry, well, not only is the two-metre rule killing it but pubs, in particular, face the galling reality of remaining closed while their beer gardens are used by hordes of people who’ve bought booze at the local supermarket.Enough already. Time, surely, for the Government to open its eyes to what’s happening around the country and exercise some common sense.Of course those who are vulnerable should continue to take as many protective measures as they wish, including remaining furloughed or off schoolnecessary.But the majority should nowto work or schooland start to get Britain back on its feet, both economically and psychologically.SCIENTISTS say that intelligent le could exist on as many as  planets in our galaxy.But they reckon aliens won’t visit Earth because of the distance.The two-week quarantine rules won’t help either.HOLLYWOOD actress Sharon Stone has revealed she was struck by lightening while doing the ironing.What a terrible shock.No, not the estimated billion volts that propelled Sharon across the kitchen, silly.The fact that a movie star was doing her own housework.TATLER magazine’s " rel"noreferrer noopener"controversial article on The Duchess of Cambridge proved that snobbery is still alive and kicking in certain sections of the British “upper” classes.Dredging up the age-old “doors to manual” jibe at Kate’s mother Carole, a former member of cabin crew, it also resurrected ancient, alleged whisperings among chinless wonders of her being “NQOCD” – not quite our class, darling.This week, Rosalind Mann died, after a -year career taking photos of posh “girls in pearls” for Country Le magazine.When asked the criteria for posing, she replied: “We never featured anyone whose house had a number.”There’s snobbery in the US too, but it’s largely centred around money, rather than class.In the compellingly vacuous Netflix series Selling Sunset, about a high-end estate agency in Hollywood, the buzz phrase is: “Millionaires have views, billionaires have compounds.”Sadly, I have neither.IN the next James Bond movie, No Time To Die, it’s reported that the legendary spy has a young daughter with Lea Seydoux’s character.Could this see those famous blue trunks being replaced by a papoose It’s tricky waters for Bond fans, with  per cent telling a recent poll that they think it’s a mistake to make the famous philanderer a family man.I’ll reserve judgment until the film is released, but suffice to say, tackling villains such as Le Chfre, Blofeld and Raoul Silva is child’s play compared to dealing with a toddler in meltdown.A PUNTER has placed a bet on Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis becoming PM by the end of .A spokesman for bookmaker Coral said: “The bet took us by surprise but someone’s convinced Maitlis could be the perfect match for No!”Presumably they’re not taking bets on which party she’d stand for as that would be too obvious.RICKY Gervais says that wherever he is in the world, he always frequents Italian restaurants because: “I know it’s going to be good and the same.”We have a similar issue at Moore Towers where – whether we’re at a Greek, French, Chinese, Italian or Japanese restaurant – the Bloke will spend aeons studying the ious culinary delights on offer before ordering “steak and chips” pretty much every time.THE stylist and “best friend” to Meghan Markle, Jessica Mulroney, is embroiled in a race row after appearing to threaten the livelihood of black lestyle blogger Sasha Exeter.Jessica, who has apologised, has now been dropped from regular TV slots and, while the pair have reportedly spoken in private, the Duchess of Sussex has yet to support her friend publicly.Something tells me that, aside from saying: “I need to do better” regarding race and injustice in society, Jessica is about to learn another valuable lesson.Hard times will always reveal true friends.CLOTHING website Missguided has been heavily criticised by shoppers after using slim models to market its plus-range of clothes in sizes  to .One said: “This screams, ‘we want to profit from plus-sized iniduals without representing or supporting them in any way’.” Very true.Equally, those ads for accessible baths showers targeted at the elderly but featuring a woman in her forties with the agility of a mountain goat.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion title: foreign aid money spent wisely
story: Having a department specically for “international development” might sound virtuous, but it makes no sense.The Foreign Office, which is in charge of building relationships with foreign countries, is perfectly placed to spend our aid money where it counts. If it had been in charge all along, our whopping aid budget would most likely have been used to fund valuable projects in fast-developing African countries — natural allies for Britain post Brexit.Thanks to the rudderless Department for International Development, it’s been squandered on things like upgrading roads in India — an enormously rich country with a fleet of new warships and a space programme to boot. The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But given this country is facing its worst recession in decades, now is hardly the moment to be sinking taxpayer cash into overseas vanity projects with no possible benefit for Brits. If Boris is determined to stick to David Cameron’s pledge to splash . per cent of GDP on foreign aid, then let’s thank our lucky stars it will now be spent wisely.THREE cheers for Marcus Rashford, a magnicent role model who yesterday won his campaign to make sure Britain’s poorest kids get one square meal a day over the summer. We know it will have been tough for the PM to swallow his pride and U-turn. But it was the right thing to do:  parents struggling to feed their children need all the help they can get right now. And £million — the cost of extending free school meal vouchers during the holidays — is a drop in the ocean when you consider the overall cost of lockdown.We like Rashford’s style, too. How refreshing to see a celebrity using his fame to articulate a powerful argument with such authenticity. NEW unemployment figures make for grim reading. The number of people claiming  jobless benefits more than doubled to hit .million in May — the  highest level since . And because the furlough scheme is masking the true extent of the crisis, we fear the worst is yet to come. Scientists are trained to think about public health  in the narrowest sense. So their instincts tell them to keep Britain in lockdown for as long as possible. But elected politicians know that  poverty and  mass unemployment kill just as surely as the virus. It’s time they showed some leadership and started easing restrictions in earnest. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must help new tories in north
story: The Manchester United and England striker forced the Government into a sudden U-turn.As a result, this summer some .million of the UK’s poorest kids will be getting free school meal vouchers.Rashford had been campaigning on the issue and wrote a letter to the Prime Minister.Good for him. The Government’s decision not to pay for the vouchers was mean-spirited and cheap.But you do wonder about a government which decides upon a policy — and then changes it as soon as a top footballer opens his mouth.Next week, Michael Gove decides to extend trade negotiations with the EU after an intervention by Harry Kane. And lockdown is lted completely when Kyle Walker says he wants to go to another house party.Still, Rashford was right and deserves credit. And he’s right, too, that the Government could go further in helping those of us who live in poverty. The pandemic has thrown the Government off course.It was bound to. But Boris and Co must remember why they were elected last December. They got a huge mandate from our country’s very poorest regions. The areas that usually support the Labour Party.That was partly because of Brexit, of course. And partly because the then Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn , was about as effective as a recently gassed badger.But it was also because Boris promised those former Labour heartlands what they wanted to hear.A closing of the ide between rich and poor, and between London and the rest of the country.Jobs, investment in new industries and transport infrastructure.He might think we’ve all forgotten. But we haven’t. The latest poll shows Labour only five points behind the Conservatives.The honeymoon is over.Boris could begin by increasing the minimum wage for people aged  and over. It is low wages, far more than unemployment, which is keeping people mired in poverty.It wouldn’t cost the Government very much at all. It would also provide a much-needed boost to the economy.An increase in free childcare from  hours per week to  hours would also enable those struggling to make ends meet to get out of the house and work for longer.Shortly after last December’s election, Boris turned up in the North East to give his thanks.He once again promised that the region would be rejuvenated.There’s been good news on some fronts — the Nissan plant at Sunderland, for example, won out over its rival in Barcelona. It will stay open, despite the loss of  jobs.But more needs to be done to attract industry to the North and the Midlands.So far as I can see, the Government has done nothing. OK, it’s had a few problems on its hands.But when this pandemic has passed, the Government will need to intervene to help our economy — the private sector alone cannot do it.And the place to start is away from London — in the places where the new breed of Tory voter lives.Marcus Rashford’s intervention was timely and needed. This Government needs to know the poor are watching and waiting. Waiting for action, waiting for the promises of last year to be delivered.THERE is a stupidity about the woke crowd, trying to ban everything, which defies belief.An old episode of Fawlty Towers was pulled. Because it had some disturbing and potentially offensive racial material in it.But as the star of it, John Cleese, tried patiently to explain – it was SATIRE.The character of Basil Fawlty was the subject of the humour. He was mocked for his idiocies. That’s why we laughed.The episode has now been reinstated – but the moron caravan has already moved on. Now they’ve got it in for Mahatma Gandhi. Racist! The bloke who fought for India’s liberation from British colonialism.Was he a racist  Yes, without much doubt. He took a pretty jaundiced view towards Africans. But the good he did easily outweighs the bad.And believe me, there isn’t a single person born before  who didn’t possess views which today’s society would consider offensive. Regarding race, or gender, or homosexuality. Not one.Why can these people not understand that the past was dferent  And that we judge its heroes in a dferent light There was a really nasty battle between the two sides, with many dead – the first time since .China continues to bully its neighbours and oppress its own people.In this battle, I know whose side I’m on.THE Government has not done much right recently.But at least Boris and Co are binning the Department for International Development.It is to be stripped of its status and merged with the Foreign Office.With any luck, this will mean we will not be giving away any more hard-earned taxpayers’ money to countries like India, which has its own space programme so is clearly not short of a bob or two.Or China – a nasty, totalitarian state and the second richest country in the world.In the last round of spending, we actually bunged money into a programme to help Chinese people improve their diets.Nope, not kidding.I wonderit mentioned anything about it maybe not being a great idea to eat bats Various studies have suggested these donations are worthless and often counter-productive.I think, right now, we need to spend money at home, no SCIENTISTS from Japan have predicted that within  years we will be able to understand what animals are thinking. We will be communicating with them.Uh-oh. Not sure that’s good. Imagine a chat with a wasp . . .“Hi, Mr Wasp. What you doing ”“I’m crawling up your window. What’s it to you  And it’s Ms Wasp, as it happens. I’ve transitioned. So don’t misgender me. Now, p*** off before I sting you on the neck.”Worse with cats. “LOVE you  WTF, I’ve never even liked you. You’re mugs, humans. Just put the food out and give me a warm place to sleep and I’ll purr for a bit to keep you happy. Now, excuse me. I’m going to sleep on the roof of the shed for six hours.”But I might start watching it now as the cast all seem to hate each other.The soap has been torn apart by rows over the Black Lives Matter debate.Lysette Anthony has taken loads of flack and her co-star Rachel Adedeji has described her as “actual trash”.Hmm . . . somehow I suspect the show will not be anywhere near as interesting as the row.NOT everything about lockdown has been bad. Far from it.My we hasn’t been to TK Maxx for three months, for a start. There’s a mercy.And we’re not using cash. There’s little indication we will need to use cash ever again.Those people who aren’t on the breadline have saved money.And then there’s offices. Will we really go back to that awful daily commute, when the vast majority of jobs can, these days, be done at home  Just think how many homes we could createwe converted all those empty offices into flats.Offices were created because we needed a place to store paper files. Don’t really need that now, do we The Government should encourage firms to move to home-working, when – the stats suggest – employees are a lot more productive.IN France – a country almost as badly hit by Covid- as the UK – the schools will be reopening on Monday. By law, no arguments. Full curriculum.Over here, meanwhile, there are suggestions that some schools will not be opening until JANUARY and will not open properly for a year. Incredible.The Government needs to get a grip of this right now, as I argued last week.Call the bluff of the horrible trade unions and get our kids back to school. Or this will be the lost generation.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teens say theyve learned nothing in lockdown
story: BEFORE lockdown, Finn Clyde was always up at am for school and was in the top sets of his classes.But since schools closed in March, the -year-old has turned his back on learning and spends all day playing on his Xbox in his room. Finn, of Carmarthen, South West Wales, says: “I don’t feel motivated to do work because I don’t always understand it.“I don’t find it fun like it is at school and I’d rather socialise online with my friends. It’s just easier than trying to do the school work.“It’s a way of escaping from everything.“I’m worried the teachers will be disappointed in me because I haven’t done enough work.“I’m worried I’ll fall behind and have to resit the year when all my friends go on.”And he is not alone. A study by University College London revealed that two million children have done barely any schoolwork at home.Since March, around  per cent of pupils have done none, or less than an hour, a day. And just  per cent put in more than four hours a day.Finn’s mum Kerrie, , a former secondary school teacher, admits she only ever sees her son at meal times.The single mum, who also has daughters Imogen, , and six-year-old Elodie, has found it hard to juggle home-schooling with working full-time as a social worker.She says: “When lockdown started I thought I’d be able to manage, especially because I used to be a teacher.“I was really motivated and ordered lots of stuff on Amazon to help. I think because the kids could see I was motivated it rubbed off on them.“But as time has gone on it’s become more dficult and challenging. I can’t give  per cent to my job and  per cent to teaching my kids. It’s just not possible.”Now Finn usually gets up around .am, has breakfast then switches on his games console — and stays up until midnight.Kerrie says: “I tried to get Finn to do schoolwork. With not enough computers for me and the kids to work, I even set written work for him.“But I couldn’t make him do it, no matter how much I encouraged him.” As we report today, more than , child health experts have signed an open letter to Boris Johnson demanding the Government publishes a clear plan to get all youngsters back to school as soon as possible or “risk scarring the le chances of a generation of young people”.The letter, organised by the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, warns children are “suffering enormously” from a lack of access to exercise, vaccinations and mental health support.m have done under an hour’s work a day, experts warn PM it will ‘scar a generation’This is par­ti­cu­larly concern­ing for Clare Cashion, , when it comes to -year-old daughter Libby.Clare, a civil servant from Worcester, who is also mum to Ollie, , Lochlan, four, and two-year-old Cullann, says: “Libby has gone from being a  hardworking student to a changed character, so I do worry about her wellbeing.”Libby now stays awake until am and usually gets up at about lunchtime. Instead of doing schoolwork, she spends most of her time talking to friends on social media.She says: “At first we didn’t know what we were supposed to be doing, and because there wasn’t proper work or anyone to check your work and because you can’t just ask questions, I didn’t want to do it.“When I did do it, I didn’t get any feedback, and then my friends would tell me they hadn’t bothered, so I just thought, ‘What’s the point ’.“I’m a huge worrier and I am concerned about falling behind, but I’d rather stay up and talk to friends on my phone. That’s when everyone is online.“Mum tries to make me do more schoolwork but it doesn’t work. There just doesn’t seem much point at the moment. “I’d just like to go back to school.”In a report last month, government advisory body Sage warned lockdown had caused a “shock” to kids that will last the rest of their lives and affect work opportunities.The report also confirmed the risk of children catching coronavirus was “much lower” than adults.Yesterday, MPs on the Education Select Committee accused teaching unions of running a “disgraceful political campaign” to keep classrooms closed by “cherry picking” evidence to make parents fear schools are “death traps”.Chairman Robert Halfon asked: “Can you explain why parents and children can have access to Primark over the coming weeks and months but not to schools ”For Libby and Clare, it will be a big relief when schools can reopen. Clare says: “School has now started online lessons, so one week they’ll be live, and  Libby has taken part in some, but the following week it’s just emails and sometimes they have to cancel.“I think Libby struggles with not knowing exactly what’s expected.”Finn is just as desperate to get back in the classroom.He said: “I really want to go back to school because it’s a lot easier to learn in a classroom with a teacher explaining the work, and I miss my independence.“I’ve found it really dficult being at home this long.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: shutdown wrecking childrens education
story: Mary Bousted, Corbynite boss of the National Education Union, apparently relished telling MPs yesterday that schools might have to stay shut into October. That is unthinkable.Top children’s doctors say the closures are doing catastrophic damage. Boris Johnson has made clear he wants schools open. Where is Sir Keir Starmer Labour’s leader knows they are safe to reopen. He has sent his own children to school throughout lockdown. But he remains mute, in fear of his MPs and the unions. His panicky confusion when put on the spot by the PM was telling.Labour’s Twitter addicts love the social media term “gaslighting”, where someone deliberately confuses an opponent so that they question their own sanity. Starmer’s MPs are trying to do the same thing to the entire nation.They, along with Labour councils and unions, have been the chief obstructions to restarting schools, having whipped up fear among teachers and parents in defiance of the scientic advice. One day scaremongering, the next denouncing the Tories for betraying kids.The reality is that Boris should now bin the -pupil class size limit and the crazy two-metre distancing edict. There is minimal evidence to support either.Then he must order schools to reopen.The shutdown is wrecking children’s education every day it grinds on.IT is vital for our economy and sanity that we can take a holiday from early July.So we urge the PM: Thrash out a deal with President Macron today, allowing free travel with France with no quarantine. Rapidly make similar “air bridge” deals with Spain, Portugal and Greece.Better still, replace the crippling, job-destroying absurdity of quarantine — its rules are too slack to work, anyway — with temperature checks at airports.Then get our hotels and B’n’Bs open for a tsunami of “staycations”.Do it now, before summer is gone and a vast number of tourism jobs with it.IT was fantastic to have the Prem back last night. And we salute all efforts toit to greater normality next season.But, we have to say, “digital health passports” sound like a recipe for turnstile chaos. And will they even be needed Yes, there could yet be a second wave. title: nicola sturgeon push date pubs reopening
story: The First Minister announced she was undertaking a fresh review of the evidence before making any final calls.But she expected to have to say that extra measures will be necessary to keep people safe.Ms Sturgeon told MSPs in the Scottish Parliament this lunchtime: There is emerging evidence that places like pubs, restaurants and gyms can be hotspots for transmission.So it is really important we better understand this evidence and what further mitigation might be necessary to protect people in such spaces before we permit them to reopen.I appreciate this will be hard for the hospitality industry. I want to give an assurance to businesses in that sector that we will continue to support preparations for reopening – for example by encouraging local authorities to facilitate the use of open outdoor spaces which pubs and restaurants can use for additional space.I expect to have this further scientic advice in two weeks and I will set out then, hopefully on or around  July, whether outdoor hospitality can re-open during phase  – which I hope will be the case – orfurther mitigations are required ahead of phase .Scotland today announced more relaxation of coronavirus rules - many of which were introduced in England within the last three weeks.People who are shielding are now able to go outside for the first time in months.And single people living alone can form a support bubble with another household - and stay at theirs overnight.Pubs in England are expected to be able to reopen on July the th, as part of Boris Johnsons roadmap for easing lockdown restrictions. But hopes of pubs serving up pints again have been marred by rows over the controversial  metre social distancing rule. If the rule is relaxed to  metre, most British pubs could reopen safely - with  metres , could have to keep their doors closed. But despite the pressure being heaped on the PM from all sides, Mr Johnson has refused to relent and has only promised a review of the rule, which will be announced before pubs reopen. Mr Johnson said the other night he would do everything in my power to get us back to normally as soon as possible, but cautioned that the UK needs to proceed carefully. Downing Streets Chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said the rule could safely be relaxed in some circumstances.He said: There are times in which this can be changed and that evidence of course can then be the basis of a policy decision on what the right distance is that should be mandated or put forward as the rule to follow. Shops will open in Scotland in the coming weeks, too.Though we are moving to phase two today, we are still being cautious and we are not going to do everything at once, Ms Sturgeon said today.We will take a staged approach to avoid bearing all of the risk at the same time.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum left disfigured after boyfriend bit ear
story: Paul Freek, , used a wooden pole to beat Lisa Norris and sank his teeth into her during the attack.Miss Norris lost two cm of cartilage from her left ear following the attack at their home in Westhoughton, near Bolton, Greater Manchester. Miss Norris told police: I cannot wear my hair in a ponytail anymore as I am worried about what people will think about the injuries on my ear.This assault has greatly impacted me and my le as I have suffered from depression and anxiety as a result and even struggle to leave the house. I have had months of sleepless nights and nightmares about how things could have gone terribly wrong.Freek, a manager for fuels firm Crown Oil, was convicted of assault occasioning actual bodily harm and jailed for two years at Bolton Crown Court.The couple had been in a relationship for about a year and moved in together around three months before the shocking incident on March  last year. They had been drinking vodka at home before getting into an argument.Prosecutor Phillip Hall said the violence started when Freek got on top of Miss Norris and punched her repeatedly in the face.Mr Hall said: She then bit him on the ear in order to try and get him off her and she did so with such force that a piece of the ear came off. He then did the same to her and a bit of her ear fell off, and he bit her nipple.He then stopped and went to the bathroom to examine his ear and it was clear a bit of it had come off. He thought he would be able to stick it back on using blood as glue but he could not.Freek then got out a wooden pole and used it to open the windows before beating her around the head, and kicking and stamping on her when she fell to the floor, the court heard.Miss Norris then blacked out.She was operated on in hospital on April  for her injuries to her ear and given stitches and antibiotics. The court heard that Freek also had signicant ear injuries and had part of his ear removed.He was arrested at home on April  where he was found hiding under a table.Freek claimed Miss Norris started biting his ear and had taken hold of his testicles and he bit her ear in self-defence.He had a previous assault conviction from  when he twisted a womans arm behind her back during a row in a pub.Sentencing, Judge Timothy Stead told Freek: This assault was particularly serious. You left her particularly distressed and your offending has had a great deal of impact on her le.You were previously convicted of battery against a woman in a pub - it cannot be said you learnt your lesson.Freek was also barred from contacting Miss Norris indefinitely under the terms of a restraining order.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: northern ireland schools 2 metre rule halved
story: The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed a  metre rule is safe and appropriate for children and young people at school.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNorthern Ireland Education Minister Peter Weir sent out a letter to school principals with guidance on how they will operate once classes do start up again, according to the BBC.The move is a hint a similar relaxation of the rule could happen UK-wide.Mr Weir said in order to give schools more time to prepare, reopening for pupils has been pushed to August . The guidance has a day one focus that concentrates on social distancing and hygiene considerations within school settings, Mr Weir wrote. The letter said: The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed that the current social distancing guidance of m must continue to be followed between all adults within the education sector, but that a distance of m is safe and appropriate between children and young people.Using protective bubbles has been supported by the Department of Health and PHA, and flexing their use to m will allow full classes to attend.The m guidance between children is to be followed as far as possible within the confines of the physical capacity of each classroom and the m rule for staff adhered to fully.To facilitate these arrangements, schools will be opening in week commencing  August for preparation purposes, he said.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said this evening the Department for Education was looking at a relaxation for the rule in England. story: Trevor Phillips, , condemned the Ruby Football Union for reviewing the popular sporting song over its ties to the slave trade.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterHe is a former head of the Commission of Racial Equality and pointed out the last people to try and ban it were Hitler and the Nazis in .Mr Phillips said the song was written by a freed slave.He wrote: So “Swing Low, Sweet Chariot”, celebrating the Underground Railway, written AFTER the Civil War by a freed slave, made popular by the African American Fisk Jubilee Singers, sung at many black funerals and civil rights demonstrations, honoured by Congress, now to be banned. It was a favourite of Paul Robeson, of Louis Armstrong and of Martin Luther King. The last attempt to ban the song was in , in Germany.So black people’s own culture is also now to be cancelled. rugby fans could be banned from singing Swing Low, Sweet Chariot at games over the song’s associations with slavery.Fans can usually be heard bellowing out the song from the stands at Twickenham but its now being examined after the Rugby Football Union launched a review into racism.The review was started after Black Lives Matter supporters called for a review of Britain’s cultural past and its context and our role in educating fans to make informed decisions.”The Twickenham ground is also covered with lyrics to the song including the line “Carry Them Home” which is also used as a marketing noopener"Sportsmail earlier this week: ”I dont think anyone at Twickenham is singing it with malicious intent, but the background of that song is complicated.”The RFU has appointed Genevieve Glover as story: New stats show the number of people having to claim universal credit has leapt .million in the past three months. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesOur map reveals in many areas more than one in ten people are now having to rely on the state. The highest percentage of claimants is in Blackpool where a staggering one in eight are now in receipt of benefits. But all areas of the country have seen massive rises amid increasing concerns the country is facing its worst jobs crisis since the s. In total, .m people are now claiming unemployment benefits, an increase of .m from March, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics .Tony Wilson, director of the Institute for Employment Studies, said: If the public health crisis is just starting to ease, these figures show that the unemployment crisis is only just beginning.Its clear, too, that this crisis is hitting many poorer areas hardest.The regional impact has changed over time.According to analysis by the Centre for Cities, during the first part of lockdown unemployment rose faster in economically weaker towns and cities, but in the past month places with stronger economies have seen larger increases in claims, which suggests that the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak has taken longer to spread south.Last week it was revealed the UK economy shrank by . per cent in April due to the coronavirus lockdown - the biggest monthly fall on record.The drop in GDP was the biggest single monthly fall since records began in , the Office for National Statisticssaid.The March plunge is also  times the average month on month decline during the global financial crisis in  , the British Chambers of Commerce said.It has also been revealed , Brits have already lost their jobs during lockdown with unemployment now set to hit three million.Experts fear the figures will in the coming months reveal the biggest drop in employment on record, laying bare the impact of the coronavirus lockdown.Early estimates from the Office for National Statistics suggest , people lost their jobs in May, on top of , the previous month.The ONS explained the numbers suggested a  per cent fall in paid employees since the country went into lockdown on March .Employment also fell by . per cent in April.The ONS deputy national economic statistician Jonathan Athow said: The slowdown in the economy is now visibly hitting the labour market, especially in terms of hours worked.Early indicators for May show that the number of employees on payrolls were down over , compared with March.Minister for Employment Mims Davies claimed the figures showed the devastation the pandemic was having on Britains workers.She said at the time: “The figures are starting to show the impact of Covid- on our economy, but our furlough scheme, grants, loans and tax cuts have protected thousands of businesses and millions of jobs, setting us up for recovery.“By responding to the needs of communities across the UK they will be at the heart of our revival and renewal, helping people find new roles and move forward with their lives.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeline mcann cops letters bungle
story: The first, saying they were treating their daughter’s disappearance as murder after finding new evidence, was dispatched at the end of May.The second was sent last week to update them on the title: struggling schools 1bn hire tutors kids catch up
story: Ministers want to ensure the “Covid Generation” can bounce back after falling behind by missing months of school ­since lockdown began in March.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt came as Boris Johnson faced pressure to follow Northern Ireland’s lead yesterday to halve social distancing to one metre to get more youngsters back into classes.The one-off cash package will see £million pumped into state schools in the next year. Another £million will fund tutoring for the most disadvantaged children.Heads will decide how the money will be spent but No  wants it to go on the most “effective” interventions such as small group tutoring.It can also be used to hire private tutors or extra teachers.The PM has been under pressure to act after going back on a vow to get all primary pupils back to class for a month before summer.Instead, only children in nursery, reception and Years One and Six have ed. In secondaries, only Years Ten and  are guaranteed any time in class before summer.It comes after a report revealed .million kids had done little or no schoolwork at home in lockdown.Unveiling his Covid Catch Up Plan, Mr Johnson said the money would help head teachers provide “extra support to children who have fallen behind while out of school”.In a message to parents juggling work and home schooling, he said: “I am determined to do ­everything I can to get all children back in school from September, and we’ll bring forward plans on how this will happen as soon as possible.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said the cash would ensure that all children will get the education, opportunities and outcomes they deserve.He said the plan would be delivered over the next academic year and bring long-term reform to education that would protect a generation of children from the effects of the pandemic.He said: “We cannot afford for any of our children to lose out as a result of Covid-.“The scale of our response must match the scale of the challenge.”Professor Becky Francis, boss of the Education Endowment Foundation charity, welcomed the money.She said: “Tutoring is the catch-up approach supported by the strongest evidence we have.“This is a tremendous opportunity to offer bespoke support for disadvantaged pupils, and build a positive legacy from the present crisis.”Meanwhile, Northern Ireland said it hoped to get all pupils back by the start of September by halving social distancing. title: air bridges boris june
story: The bridges could allow Brits to skip quarantine when arriving back in the UK after travelling, as well as any isolation requirements in the selected countries.This could include Greece, Portugal and Spain, as well as overseas UK territories including Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands and Gibraltar. The Foreign Office is also expected to relax its guidance against Brits making any non-essential travel abroad.An source told The : “The plan is to announce a small number of air bridges on June , though it won’t come into force until July .“Obviously it will depend on factors such as the scientic advice and the level of coronavirus infections at the time.June  is the date for the Governments first review of its controversial quarantine policy, which came into force last week.The Health Secretary Matt Hancock confirmed to Radio s Today programme yesterday that the government is close to introducing travel corridors with certain countries soon - meaning there would be no need for travellers to quarantine on arrival in the UK. Mr Hancock said: Thats the plan. The quarantine policy is important because there are some countries around the world where this virus is not under control, however, theres other countries where it may be safe to be able to not have a quarantine in place.So ahead of the formal review of the quarantine arrangements on the th of June, Im working with Grant Shapps on whether there are countries that have a low rate of infection where we can come to an agreement on a travel corridor.Travel between the UK and France will also be raised in a meeting between the two countries this week, Boris Johnson has said.The Prime Minister is believed to have talked with French president Emmanuel Macron about how people can move safely between the two countries when Mr Macron came to Britain yesterday.He also reiterated that air bridges, enabling holidaymakers to travel overseas without entering self-isolation when they , were being considered.It comes after Transport Secretary Grant Shapps indicated that the Government is actively working on introducing travel corridors, to help the struggling tourism industry.Speaking at Tuesdays Downing Street press conference, Mr Johnson said: Obviously I will be talking to Emmanuel Macron about all sorts of ways in which we can bring our countries together, making sure that eventually we will be able to travel freely to and from each others countries.The same goes obviously for Spain, as soon as we can.The reason for having the quarantine system is very simple - we dont want to re-import the disease just at the moment when weve really got it under control in this country.But were certainly looking at air bridges and ways to ensure that people can safely go on holiday eventually.Most international arrivals into the UK are required to go into self-isolation for  days, while in France, a two-week quarantine is currently in place for UK visitors.Earlier on Tuesday, Mr Shapps told LBC radio: We wont be in a position to announce which countries - where reciprocal arrangements go in place - until the th.So dont expect anything this week, I think Im right in saying its only the end of next week.All passengers, bar a handful of exemptions, have to fill out an online locator form giving their contact and travel details, as well as the address of where they will isolate.Mr Shapps said the measure was introduced because we dont want to go back to kind of importingor Brits going abroad and bringing it back with them.A group of more than  travel and hospitality businesses campaigning against the policy said last week they had received private assurances from senior Government sources that travel corridors will be in place from June .Spain has warned that it may impose its own -day quarantine requirement for UK tourists.Foreign affairs minister Arancha Gonzalez Laya told the BBCs Hardtalk programme: We will be checking what the UK will be doing and we will be in dialogue with the UK to see whether or not we should be introducing reciprocity as they have dferent measures than the rest of the EU.She added: The health situation ... is a little bit better in Spain than it is in the UK.This came after Spains prime minister Pedro Sanchez announced over the weekend that tourists from many European nations would be welcome from June .A number of other countries on the continent eased their border restrictions on Monday, but many have maintained entry restrictions for UK holidaymakers.Destinations that do not require UK holidaymakers to enter quarantine include Belgium, Portugal, Italy and Switzerland.Airline trade body the International Air Transport Association said rapid Covid- testing of passengers from countries considered as higher risk could remove the need for burdensome and intrusive measures such as quarantine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: covid alert level 3 uk
story: Health Secretary Matt Hancock described the move as “big moment for the country” and praised Brits’ determination to beat the disease.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Government’s chief medical officers, led by Prof Chris Whitty, say transmission of the bug is no longer high or rising exponentially.It prompted the Joint Biosecurity Centre to advise ministers they could reduce the alert level from four to three on their five-point scale.This allows for a “gradual relaxation of restrictions and social distancing measures” - raising hopes that the two-metre rule could be eased.It comes as:Sources say it has no immediate implications but gives ministers confidence they can take further steps towards ending lockdown at the start of July.This is likely to include reducing the two metre social distancing rule and allowing pubs, restaurants and cafes to reopen.The Government has been under pressure to scrap the strict measure by schools and the hospitality sector who are worried they cannot fully reopen.Mr Hancock said: “The UK moving to a lower alert level is a big moment for the country, and a real testament to the British peoples determination to beat this virus.“The Governments plan is working.“Infection rates are rapidly falling, we have protected the NHS and, thanks to the hard work of millions in our health and social care services, we are getting the country back on her feet.”A joint statement from the CMOs said: “The Joint Biosecurity Centre has recommended that the Covid- alert level should move from Level to Level  .“There has been a steady decrease in cases we have seen in all four nations, and this continues.“It does not mean that the pandemic is over. The virus is still in general circulation, and localised outbreaks are likely to occur.“We have made progress against the virus thanks to the efforts of the public and we need the public to continue to follow the guidelines carefully to ensure this progress continues.”  The Prime Minister unveiled the five-stage coronavirus warning system as part of a gradual easing of the lockdown during a televised address on May .He said he was establishing a new joint biosecurity centreto run the alert system, which is similar to that used to establish the terrorist threat.The group would detect increases in Covid- infection rates and judge how strict lockdown measures and social distancing rules should be.Two factors determine the UKs coronavirus threat level - the R number and the number of confirmed Covid- infections at any one time.The alert levels range from level one - green - to level five - red.When the scheme was launched, the country was at level four, which means a Covid- epidemic is in general circulation, transmission is high or rising exponentially.The system says that current social distancing measures and restrictions should remain in place.Level five is when transmission is high or rising but also when there was a risk of healthcare services being overwhelmed and will require an increase in social distancing measures.Level one means Covid- is no longer known to be in the UK and the only action should be routine international monitoring.Level three is when the epidemic is in general circulation and gradual easing of restrictions can take place, while level two is when the number of cases and transmission is low and no or minimal restrictions are required.But under level two there will be enhanced testing, tracing, monitoring and screening.At the end of May, Mr Johnson told MPs that were coming down the Covid alert system from level four to level three tomorrow, we hope, were going to be taking a decision tomorrow.But the alert level was not lowered - despite the easing of some restrictions - and it remained at four until now.Representatives from industries, such as the hospitality sector, may hope it could also pave the way for the two-metre rule to be relaxed which is key for many pubs, restaurants and cafes to reopen.Prof Matt Keeling, of Warwick University, believes the downgrade is currently justied but cautions against the easing of social distancing.He said: The move to level three is not a time for complacency, there is still the prospect of a second wavecontrols are relaxed too quickly and the reproductive numberrises above one.We are likely to be entering a new phase of this outbreak, where nationally and regionally cases will continue to decline, but locally there will be isolated clusters of cases that need to be contained.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tensions north korea south korea
story: On Wednesday North Korea said it would redeploy troops after rejecting the South’s offer to send special envoys to ease tensions.North Korea said it would send troops to inter-Korean cooperation sites on its territory, rebuild guard posts and restart military drills at the northern side of the border with South Korea. The news, which was reported by state news agency KCNA, would nully the  deals that ban both Koreas from taking any hostile acts against each other.A spokesman for the General Staff of theKorean People’s Armysaid the country would dispatch troops to Mount Kumgang and Kaesong near the border.Police posts that were withdrawn from the Demilitarized Zone will be reinstalled, while artillery units near the western sea border would be reinforced with the alert heightened to the level of “top-class combat duty”, the spokesman said. This comes days after Pyongyang destroyed the joint liaison office that had been set up in the border town of Kaesong as part of their peace agreements. On Monday South Korea’s President, Moon Jae-in offered to send his national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, and spy chief Suh Hoon to Pyongyang as special crises and suggesting “preposterous proposals.”KCNA said: “The solution to the present crisis between the North and the South caused by the incompetence and irresponsibility of the South Korean authorities is impossible and it can be terminated only when the proper price is paid.In response, President Moon’s office said that the South would no longer accept “unreasonable behaviour” by the North.South Korea’s defence ministry warned of the dangers of military actions saying.Jeon Dong-jin, the director of operations at the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said: “These moves thwart two decades of efforts by South and North Korea to improve inter-Korean relations and to keep peace on the Korean peninsular.If the North actually takes such a move, it will certainly pay the price for it.The KPA said on Tuesday it had been studying an action plan to re-enter zones that had been demilitarised under a  inter-Korean military pact and turn the front line into a fortress.Seouls defence ministry has urged North Korea to abide by the agreement, under which both sides agreed to cease all hostile acts and dismantled a number of structures along the DMZ. Despite rising tensions, South Korea said title: kate middleton beams garden centre public appearance lockdown
story: The Duchess of Cambridge carried out her first public engagement in months at Fakenham Garden Centre near her Norfolk home of Anmer Hall.Kate, , wore dark jeans, a padded waistcoat and Superga khaki trainers and respected social distancing guidelines.As a keen gardener, she wanted to learn how the coronavirus outbreak had affected the family-run independent business.She told owners Martin and Jennie Turner she loved visiting garden centres with her three children - Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.She said, smiling: “They love it. It’s such a great space for children and families to come to garden centres.“I’ve been food shopping but I have to say I haven’t been out a huge amount more, but it’s good and so important, now as things start to ease, people know they can go out and particularly to places like this.”Garden centres were allowed to reopen last month as lockdown restrictions were eased. Prince William and Prince Charles ed to royal duty earlier this week.The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall met NHS heroes in the grounds of Gloucestershire Royal Hospital in Gloucester on Tuesday.The Duke of Cambridge visited ambulance workers in Kings Lynn, Norfolk.The family have spent much of the lockdown at Anmer Hall.While unable to attend their usual royal events, they have been holding virtual visits to care centres and hospitals via video calls.Britain’s coronavirus alert level has been lowered from four to three. It paves the way for a relaxation of the two-metre rule.Health Secretary Matt Hancock described the move as a “big moment for the country”.He praised Brits’ determination to beat the disease as the number of deaths continues to fall.The Government’s chief medical officers say transmission of the bug is no longer rising exponentially.Kate said she and husband William had found the social effects of the pandemic unsettling.She said: “When we do our food shopping we notice that everyone keeps their head down and it’s hard for that social interaction.”Spending time outdoors is a cornerstone of the Duchess’s work with youngsters and is something she encourages her own children to do as much as possible.The Duchess revealed that George loved to play with Venus flytrap plants at garden centres, and at home the three children have been growing tomatoes.Kate said: “They were very excited to grow them from seeds and now they’re as tall as them.”The garden centre owner Mr Turner told Kate about some the dficulties his centre had faced over the last three months.He said: “This has been the most challenging thing we’ve ever experienced.“We completely shut until after Easter and then we opened for some collections and deliveries in the car park.“We have  staff and we had to furlough around  due to closing the coffee shop and family members shielding or childcare issues.“Four or five people have very unfortunately had to be made redundant, as going forward we can’t sustain them.”But once they started to trade again three weeks ago, he said people had flocked back to buy plants.“There’s been a massive upsurge hasn’t there as people have been spending so much time outdoors and in their gardens,” he said.Meeting garden workers Michaela Giura, , from Norwich, and Tobias Davies, , she askedthey were glad to be back - smiling in agreement when they askedshe was too.“It’s good to get a structure and a routine back isn’t it ”.The Duchess also met Sam Wade, , from Fakenham, who had been working in the coffee shop but was retrained by daughter Polly Wade, , to use the tills.Mr Wade said: “It’s amazing that Kate came and showed everyone were open for business.“That’s exactly what the royals should be doing.”Kate’s trip to the garden centre was followed by the Duke of Cambridge visiting Smiths the Bakers on Friday, which has been serving King’s Lynn for  years.It reopened its premises on Monday after  weeks in lockdown.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
